items.title:
Title * recommended

Page Title

This is the main title of your page. If you don't set a page title, title will be inherited from folder name. Page title is used for the following:

  • <h1> large title at the top of page content.
  • <title> meta tag used for SEO and social sharing.
  • Page/folder listing pages.
  • Carousel- and list mega menu.

HTML Tags

Some html tags are supported in the page title:
<a><span><em><i><b><strong><small><s>

*Html tags are stripped from menu items.

Menu Label * optional

Menu Label

Use the menu label to set a short title for the main menu. If you don't set a menu label, label will be inherited from folder name. Unlike titles, menu labels should be as short as possible, so they fit nicely into the menu.

HTML Tags

Some html tags are supported in the menu label:
<span><em><i><b><strong><small><img><svg>

* Mega menu carousel will use titles instead of label.
* label can also be used in folders-listings.

Description * recommended

Page Description

The page description is normally displayed below the title in the page, and in the page description meta tag, used for social sharing and in search listings. Descriptions are not strictly required, but we recommend a short description for each page.

  • You don't need to display descriptions in the page, even if you set one.
  • Descriptions will display in Google search listings, and when sharing on social media.
  • There are no limitations to the length of a page description, but a thumbrule would be to keep a single sentence (or two), and maximum 160 characters.

HTML Tags

* Some html tags are supported in the description:
<a><span><em><i><b><strong><small><s><br><mark><img><kbd><code><button>

Date * optional

Page Date

Date is only used for pages where you are displaying date in the page context module, for example blog-like pages. Therefore, it is not required to fill this field. If you are displaying date in the page and don't set a specific date, it will use the date from when the page was last updated.

Format

Although you can add the date as you like, we recommend the standardized format YYYY-MM-DD, year-month-day in numerals. The date format may display differently in your website, depending on your settings in global Settings › Advanced › Date Format.

Preview Image

Preview Image

Set a unique preview image for the page. Preview images are used for:

  • Folder listing pages.
  • Page context module if 'preview' item is set.
  • Mega menu carousel and list.
  • Sharing on social media og:image.

Empty Preview Image

If you leave the field empty, X3 will automatically find a preview image:

  1. preview.jpg in folder, if file exists.
  2. First image in folder if folder has images.
  3. preview.jpg from your index page, if file exists.
  4. First image from index page, if index page has images.
  5. Default X3 preview image.

Instructions

Select an image from the dropdown list, or simply go to the page gallery and click the flag icon to set a preview image. Optionally, you can use Panel Tools › Previews to automatically apply preview images to all your pages, where possible.

Preview image from another folder
If you want to apply a preview image from a different folder, you will need to add the full file path relative to the content folder. Example: 2.galleries/3.style/van.jpg

Tip!

If you want to include a preview image in a page without creating a gallery, simply upload an image with file name preview.jpg. This specific file name is hidden from the page gallery, and is exclusively reserved for setting a preview image.

The dropdown option allows top-level pages to include special "mega menu" functionality.

There are four types of mega-menu:

Modules

A few settings for all page modules.

Modules

What are page modules?

Page modules are the three components which make up the page-specific content: context, folders and gallery.

context

The context module contains all page context, which may include title, description, date, amount and content.

folders

The folders module will display all subfolders (child-pages) of the current page. If the current page does not have subfolders, the module will not display.

* Folders module will only display on the page if the page contains child-pages (subfolders).

gallery

The gallery module will display all images of the current page. If the current page does not have any images, the module will not display.

* Gallery module will only display if the page contains images.

items.title:
Page Modules [tags]

Page Modules

This setting is used to set the layout- and order of modules in the page

* Add items by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Examples

By default, context will display first, followed by page folders, and gallery. Normally, you won't have both folders and images in the same page.contextfoldersgallery

In some cases, you may wish to switch the order of page modules. In the below example, gallery displays before the page context.gallerycontextfolders

If you remove the gallery module, it will not display in the page, even if the page has images.contextfolders

context,folders,gallery

Module Width

Module Width

This option sets the layout width for all modules in the page.

* You can override the width of each module specifically from the module's settings. For example, you may want a narrow layout for context, and a wide layout for the gallery.

Responsive

Layout width options are responsive, and are relative to the device screen width. For example on small mobile devices, this option has no effect, because the modules will scale down to device max width anyway. This option mainly affects desktop-sized screens, where the module content may need to be contained inside a functional viewing area.

Options

wide The wide option sets the module to display at 100% screen width. It can be useful for many folders- and gallery layouts (especially slideshow), but should not be used for context.

default This is the default option, where the module is wrapped inside a default 1140 px maximum width. This ensures that module content remains within functional viewing areas also on very large screens.

narrow This option sets a relatively narrow layout, which is often suitable for context (text). Text content should be limited by width, because optimal human reading is limited to 50-80 characters per line (like a book).

narrower This option sets a narrower module layout, which is very functional for context (text). This is the default width for the context module.

narrowest This option sets a very narrow module layout, which is suitable for very specific content, for example a contact form.

CSS Classes [tags]

Module Classes

Module classes are CSS classes that are applied to all modules in your page (context, folders, gallery). You can add native X3 classes or custom CSS classes here.

Crop Preview Images

Crop Folders Preview Images

This setting allows you to crop the preview images which display in the folders module. The advantage of cropped images, is that it provides a consistent layout because all images listed are the same size. If you don't enable crop, you can still use preview images, but they will display at original aspect ratios.

items.title:
Select Layout

Folders Layout

Select a layout for the folders page module.

Grid

Use the grid method to create robust grid layouts, which respond nicely to different screen widths.

Vertical

Simply list images vertically in a blog-like style. Functional, responsive and works nicely on all devices.

Justified

Use the justified method to create neat layouts with images of different aspects. Justified will scale images within rows to allow an elegant layout which the fills space available.

Columns

Use the columns method to create a vertical masonry-style layout which emphasizes portrait aspect images. Columns will scale images within columns to allow an elegant layout which fills space available.

Carousel

The carousel method displays multiple items in a horizontal carousel layout. The carousel is useful for teaser pages.

items.helpvalue:
Grid Layout

Grid Layout

Use the grid method to create robust grid layouts which can respond to different screen sizes. Unless your images are all the same aspect, you should use the crop setting to achieve a uniform layout. There are two ways to configure the grid layout:

Set Amount

Set a fixed amount of columns for your grid.

Set Width

Set a target width for columns in the grid. The amount of columns created, will depend on the horizontal space available (module width and screen size). By using this setting, you will get a progressive amount of columns.

items.title:
Columns Amount [large, medium, small screen-size]

Grid Columns

Create a grid layout by defining the amount of columns available in the grid on large, medium and small screens.

Examples

The default grid displays 3 columns on large screens, 2 columns on small screens and a single column on small (mobile) screens.321

Add more columns to create a thumbnails-like layout. In this example, we have 6 columns on large screens, 3 columns on medium screens, and 1 column on small screens. * We recommend a single column on small screens (mobile devices), because it simply works best.631

By omitting values for medium- and small screens, you can set an amount of columns that apply for all screen sizes. Keep in mind, when doing such, your grid columns will scale down on small devices.3

Column Width [px]

Column Width

Set a target width for columns in the grid. The amount of columns created, will depend on the horizontal space available (module width and screen size). By using this setting, you will get a progressive amount of columns.

* When using width, the grid layout is automatically responsive. Large screens will fit many columns, while small screens will fit fewer columns.

Grid Space

The amount of space in px between grid items.

Vertical Layout

The vertical method simply creates a layout where images are stacked vertically and respond to screen width. This layout is simple but effective for scrolling through items both on desktop- and small touchscreen devices. It is recommended to use the vertical layout with the narrow module width.

Justified Layout

Justified Layout Settings

Use the justified method to create neat layouts with images of different aspects. Justified layout will scale images to fit within specified row target height, allowing elegant layouts that fill the available space.

* Justified layout is not compatible with meta-data (title, description etc), unless you use captions-overlay or tooltip.

* The justified layout is responsive by nature, since images will fill each row at whatever width is available.

items.title:
Row Height [px]

Target Row Height

Set a target row-height, where images will be scaled within. The larger the target-height, the larger the images are, but fewer images will fit inside each row.

* The justified layout will calculate height of each row based on target-height and the amount- and aspect of images inside. Sometimes, you may get an orphan-image on a separate row at the bottom.

Space [px]

Space

Space in px between items in the justified layout.

Since the justified grid often stacks images vertically on small mobile devices anyway, it may be unnecessary to process them in a justified layout. Furthermore, it is often easier for visitors on small mobile devices to simply scroll through images stacked vertically.

* Images will stack vertically on small mobile devices.
* Justified layout will still work on tablets 700px and up.
* This setting may be beneficial for galleries with several hundred images.

Settings for the page gallery module.

Gallery Module

What is the page gallery module?

The gallery module is part of the page layout that displays the page's images. There are many layout-options and styles to choose from for the gallery module.

* Settings here are inherited from global settings › page › gallery.

* The gallery module will only display in the page if the page contains images.

items.title:
Module Width

Gallery Module Width

This option sets the width for the gallery module. We generally recommend 'wide' for slideshow, 'narrow' for vertical layout, while grid-, columns- and justified layouts work well in both wide and default.

Responsive

Layout width options are responsive, and are relative to the device screen width. For example on small mobile devices, this option has no effect, because the modules will scale down to device max width anyway. This option mainly affects desktop-sized screens, where the module content may need to be contained inside a functional viewing area.

Options

Wide The wide option sets the module to display at 100% screen width. This will effectively.

Default This is the default option, where the module is wrapped inside a default 1140 px maximum width. This ensures that module content remains relatively wide, but within a functional viewing areas also on very large screens.

Narrow This option sets a relatively narrow layout, which is often suitable for context (text). Text content should be limited by width, because optimal human reading is limited to 50-80 characters per line (like a book).

Narrower This option sets a narrower module layout.

Narrowest This option sets a very narrow module layout.

Items [tags]

Gallery Items

This setting is used to set items for images in the gallery module, and in which order the items display. The following items are available: titledatedescriptionpreview.

As a general guideline, you would only use preview item for slideshow-, columns- and justified layouts, and instead use the caption setting if you need to display title and/or description. The vertical- and grid- layouts are suitable if you want to display title and/or description above or below the preview image.

* Add items by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Crop Images

This setting allows you to crop images which display in the gallery module. The advantage of cropped images, is that it offers a uniform layout because all images will be the same size. Normally, you would want to use crop for the grid layout, and the carousel layout.

* When using the justified or columns layout, image crop will be ignored. These layouts are specifically for images of different aspects, and this allows you to keep crop as a default for other layouts.

* When images are clicked and opened in the popup slideshow module, they will nautrally be displayed in original non-cropped aspect.

Aspect Ratio

Use the aspect ratio to decide the crop ratio of the image. For example 1:1 will display a symmetrical square image, 2:1 will display a wide image, while 1:2 will create a tall image. It all depends on your images, and the layout you are using.

Set Amount

Set a fixed amount of columns for your grid.

Set Width

Set a target width for columns in the grid. The amount of columns created, will depend on the horizontal space available (module width and screen size). By using this setting, you will get a progressive amount of columns.

Create a grid layout by defining the amount of columns available in the grid on large, medium and small screens.

Examples

Add more columns to create a thumbnails-like layout. In this example, we have 6 columns on large screens, 3 columns on medium screens, and 1 column on small screens. * We recommend a single column on small screens (mobile devices), because it simply works best.631

* Justified layout is not compatible with meta-data (title, description etc), unless you use captions-overlay or tooltip.

* Justified layout will still work on tablets 700px and up.
* This setting may be beneficial for galleries with several hundred images.

Slideshow Layout

Gallery Slideshow Layout

The slideshow is a powerful gallery layout that supports touchscreen gestures, keyboard, thumbnails, autoplay, fullscreen, video and much more. The slideshow method comes with comprehensive settings to account for a variety of layout combinations.

* The slideshow should normally be used with the wide gallery module width.

items.inlinetitle:
Use as Intro

Slideshow Intro

When enabled, your gallery slideshow will be positioned as an intro at top of page, behind the main menu. This feature is useful for start pages and special feature pages.

[View demo]

* By enabling this setting, slideshow will always be placed at top of page at full width.
* It is recommended to use the "cover" fit for slideshow intro.

items.title:
Menu Style

Menu Style

Since the main menu is overlaying the slideshow, we use white text on a semi-transparent dark background by default, to make sure the menu remains visible.

* Menu style only applies for the topbar layouts.

normal
Keeps the default menu colors. Often, this will not create enough contrast to layer the menu on top of the slideshow.

white
Sets the menu text color to white, which makes the menu optimally visible when layered above the slideshow.

white on 12% black * default
Sets the menu text color to white, and adds a 12% semi-transparent dark background behind the menu. This is often required to make sure the menu is visible when layered on top of the slideshow.

white on 25% black
Sets the menu text color to white, and adds a 25% semi-transparent dark background behind the menu.

items.inlinetitle:
Show Scroll Down Button

Show Scroll Down Button

Adds a "down" button at bottom of slideshow-intro, which hints to the visitor that there is more content below. When the button is clicked, the page will scroll to the bottom of slideshow, effectively displaying the content below the slideshow. This feature is useful for intro-slideshows set to 100% height, when it's important that the visitor is made aware that there is more page content below the slideshow.

Remove scroll button on scroll down

Remove scroll button on scroll down

When enabled, the scroll button will dissappear once the visitor scrolls down (more than 100px), or after clicking the scroll button.

A shortcut to entirely hide page context (title, description, content etc).

items.title:
Height [% or px]

Slideshow Canvas Height

Height of the slideshow canvas inside the gallery module. Unlike the width setting, 100% height indicates that the slideshow should take 100% height of device viewport.

* This setting does not dictate the image height, but sets the available height for the image to display within. Actual image height will depend on image aspect, screen aspect and "fit" setting.

Ratio [empty = disabled]

Slideshow Ratio

If enabled, ratio will override the height setting, and instead set the height of slideshow based on width and the aspect ratio setting. The advantage of this setting, is that it can make sure the slideshow retains a specific aspect ratio across all screen sizes, even mobile devices with different vertical orientation.

* You would normally use this setting if all your images are the same aspect ratio.

2/1 This gives a 2-to-1 wide aspect ratio.

2 This is the same as above.

1/2 This gives a 1-to-2 tall aspect ratio.

0.5 This is the same as above.

4/3 This gives a 4-to-3 wide aspect ratio.

1.33 This is the same as above.

* When using ratio, slideshow canvas height may still be limited by browser viewport height.

Fit

Slideshow Fit

This option decides how images scale within the available slideshow canvas. Normally, you would choose between the cover or contain settings.

cover
Will scale images so they cover the entire slideshow stage. This looks elegant, but will often hide small parts of the image outside of the stage, so that it fits nicely. This effect is especially suitable for slideshow "intro" mode.

contain
This setting will scale images so they fit within the slideshow stage area without hiding parts of the image. This ensures the image is entirely visible, but there will be empty gaps either above/below or left/right of the image.

scaledown
This is the same as the cover-setting, except it will never scale images up.

none
With this setting, slideshow images will not get scaled. This is NOT recommended, because if it does not scale down images on small devices, the may become entirely un-viewable.

Video Intro Plugin

The video-background plugin allows you to use a video as page background. This plugin can be useful on your home page, or to emphasize certain special pages. To add a video-background to any page, simply upload an mp4 video file, and set the video source.

[see demo]

Limitations

  • Does not work on mobile
    Unfortunately, the video-background does not work on mobile devices for several reasons. Instead, there is a fallback for mobile devices. * See details in mobile fallback section below.
  • Video Cropped
    As you may understand, for a background video to display nicely at any height, on any device, on any screen aspect, the video may be cropped appropriately to 'fit' the designated stage area.
  • Does not work for sidebar layout
    Because of the huge technical difference of this layouts, the video intro plugin currently only works for the topbar- and slidemenu layouts.
  • H.264 encoded mp4 format
    Video in HTML5 is limited by various file formats and codecs. To be sure that your video displays properly across all browsers, the video should be encoded in H.264 codec, in mp4 format [ref].
  • 2MB Upload Limit
    Your host may have a 2MB upload limitation, in which case you would need to upload large video files by FTP into appropriate folders.
  • Browser remembers play-state
    If a visitor clicks to 'pause' the video, the video will also be paused next time the page loads. This is just common sense.
  • Results of slow internet
    If your video file is large, and the visitor is on a relatively slow connection, they may see the video start- and stop frequently while buffering.
  • Autoplay disabled
    Some visitors have simply disabled autoplay from their browser, in which case the video simply won't autoplay.
  • Loop stitch
    Don't expect the video loop to stich seamlessly on all browsers, even if your video is made to do so. Depending on the browser, it might take several milliseconds before the video starts re-playing.

Mobile Fallback

For several obvious reasons, background-video will not display for mobile devices, and will instead display the poster image (or poster-mobile image), which is an acceptable fallback.

  • Most mobile devices (including iphone/ipad) do not allow autoplay, mainly to prevent unsolicited cellular download. There is no "fix" for this.
  • Even if the video was loaded in pause-mode, clicking the native play button would open the video in a player-window, so it wouldn't be a background video.
  • A video may require too much bandwidth, and will often stutter on mobile.

Recommendations

The background-video plugin is intended to be used as a motion-background to compliment the page content. Don't use video just because you can or because it looks nice. We recommend using a short, subtle video loop, without sound, lasting only a few seconds, and compressed at acceptable file size.
